data.title: L’imprimerie des dominicains de Mossoul: une contribution à la mémoire culturelle des chrétiens d’Orient
data.abstractNote: The recent, dramatic events in Iraq and Syria have drawn attention to the situation of the Christians in the Middle-East. This is not the first time that the Christian presence has been threatened. Since 1850, the Italian and later the French Dominican friars have worked very hard to strengthen the local Chaldean and Syriac Churches, trying to improve the educational level of the faithful and the clergy. The Dominican printing house of Mosul, established in 1860, is one of the main elements in this effort. From its inception to 1915, when the Turks destroyed it, the Mosul printing house published a large quantity of educational and religious books in Arabic, Syriac, Aramaic, Turkish, and French, making a major contribution to the revival of these Christian oriental traditions.
